com.defano.jmonet.tools

Class SelectionTool

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.defano.jmonet.tools.base.PaintTool
      • com.defano.jmonet.tools.base.AbstractSelectionTool
        • com.defano.jmonet.tools.SelectionTool
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    CanvasCommitObserver, SurfaceInteractionObserver, MutableSelection, TransformableSelection, MarchingAntsObserver, KeyListener, EventListener

    public class SelectionTool
extends AbstractSelectionTool
    A tool for drawing a rectangular selection on the canvas.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      SelectionTool() 

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      protected void addSelectionPoint(Point initialPoint, Point newPoint, boolean isShiftKeyDown)
      Invoked to indicate that the user has defined a new point on the selection path.
      void adjustSelectionBounds(int xDelta, int yDelta)
      Invoked to indicate that the selection should be moved on the canvas and therefore the selection shape's coordinates should be translated accordingly.
      protected void completeSelection(Point finalPoint)
      Invoked to indicate that the given point should be considered the last point in the selection path.
      Shape getSelectionOutline()
      Gets the bounding selection shape of the current selection outline, i.e., the path on which "marching ants" will be drawn.
      void resetSelection()
      Reset the selection boundary to its initial, no-selection state.
      void setSelectionOutline(Rectangle bounds)
      Specifies the selection rectangle (bounds) of the current selection, i.e., the rectangular path on which "marching ants" will be drawn.

      • SelectionTool

        public SelectionTool()

    • Method Detail

      • getSelectionOutline

        public Shape getSelectionOutline()
        Gets the bounding selection shape of the current selection outline, i.e., the path on which "marching ants" will be drawn.
        Returns:
        The selection outline

      • addSelectionPoint

        protected void addSelectionPoint(Point initialPoint,
                                 Point newPoint,
                                 boolean isShiftKeyDown)
        Invoked to indicate that the user has defined a new point on the selection path.
        Specified by:
        addSelectionPoint in class AbstractSelectionTool
        Parameters:
        initialPoint - The first point defined by the user (i.e., where the mouse was initially pressed)
        newPoint - A new point to append to the selection path (i.e., where the mouse is now)
        isShiftKeyDown - When true, indicates user is holding the shift key down

      • completeSelection

        protected void completeSelection(Point finalPoint)
        Invoked to indicate that the given point should be considered the last point in the selection path.
        Specified by:
        completeSelection in class AbstractSelectionTool
        Parameters:
        finalPoint - The final point on the selection path.

      • resetSelection

        public void resetSelection()
        Reset the selection boundary to its initial, no-selection state. MutableSelection.getSelectionOutline() should return null following a selection reset, but prior to defining a new selection.

      • setSelectionOutline

        public void setSelectionOutline(Rectangle bounds)
        Specifies the selection rectangle (bounds) of the current selection, i.e., the rectangular path on which "marching ants" will be drawn.
        Parameters:
        bounds - The new selection bounds.

      • adjustSelectionBounds

        public void adjustSelectionBounds(int xDelta,
                                  int yDelta)
        Invoked to indicate that the selection should be moved on the canvas and therefore the selection shape's coordinates should be translated accordingly.
        Parameters:
        xDelta - Number of pixels to move selection bounds horizontally.
        yDelta - Number of pixels to move selection bounds vertically.
